displayed_text: Patient: Yeah. It depends. Sometimes I’m on gel pills and sometimes I’m on pills, pills. Doctor: So, those are the three medicines you take? Patient: Yes. Doctor: So the Eliquis, the Wellbutrin, and your calcium with vitamin D in it? Patient: Right. Doctor: Nothin’ new? Nothing new for bowels? Anything for pain? Patient: No. Doctor: Okay. (Pause10sec) Patient: No. Doctor: Heart failure? Patient: No. Doctor: Any issues with – did you ever have a blood transfusion?

Patient: And I can drive afterwards? Doctor: Oh yeah. Patient: So it’s not necessary for her to come down? Family Member: So I don’t have to go for that one. Doctor: Right. That one you can… Family Member: But then he’ll need a bone biopsy? Doctor: Because that day though he will be signing the consent for the study so. Family Member: Unless we want to read it through. Patient: Okay so uh… Doctor: So it could be on a Thursday or a Friday if you’re okay with that. Patient: Uh… Doctor: That we can get the echo in that’s about…

Patient: Okay. Doctor: We have a number of clinical studies uh, that, uh, are in various per deviations of what we could do. Um. So, we || um, have a study of chemotherapy. Patient: Uh, huh. Doctor: Plus vitamin C. That was data that suggest that vitamin C may reduce the side effects from the chemotherapy, may enhance its activity. We don’t know that. That’s a research question. And, so, um then, you are going to go on chemotherapy and are willing to participate, get randomized to get the vitamin C or a dummy infusion. Patient: Right. Doctor: Um. That is cumbersome for someone like you. Uh, you’d have to come in at least twice a week to get the vitamin C. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: The chemo is every three weeks, but the vitamin C is in high doses and it’s infusion. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, uh, and, as of now, I still think even the placebo equaled yet a dummy infusion. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, so, you come in and maybe get tons of sugar. Um. And, we’re trying to sort out side effects of the Docetaxel, and then we can sort of compare it between the two groups --- is, do people have better PSA responses, longer PSA responses or there is no benefit to adding the vitamin C? Patient: Yeah. Okay.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, your January/February scan had maybe something on your adrenal glands, maybe something in your liver, maybe some clumpy lymph nodes, and you’re like oh, okay. So, when I sent you over for like additional, you know, trials you had areas to measure outside your bone but then you kind of don’t. So, on your last CAT scan we couldn’t see anything where the liver was so that’s just not there, the lymph nodes kind of where the adrenal area was is enlarged so you don’t fit that. Oh, that’s wonderful. You made my life a living bleep when I was like oh, yay, but oh, yay, oh, yay, oh. Patient: Right. Doctor: So, I’m thrilled that you don’t have the cancer that we say earlier that might have been from the pills you were on Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: but then I’m kind of stuck in terms of well, I’m not really sure if I know where you are right now in October. So, sometimes when I get a little bit stuck and I’m trying to well, there’s this and that, just stop. It doesn’t have to be a mystery because we can just do a full set. So, like you should get a bone scan because the last time was July and we’re in October. You’re in pain so maybe I got to look for new spots that we have to try to treat. That’s one. Then, you know, a bone scan and then a CAT scan, but one that also includes the chest to make sure I’m not missing anything up higher that maybe is causing some of the lower pain. So, I think from here to here and your bone scan we can get that in a few days. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I’m not gonna fuss. I’m gonna fast forward to say well, whatever that shows I think the question is, you know, what are my options. So, here’s where I’m at. If it’s more than bone, meaning, oh, shoot, maybe that thingy in the liver and the lymph nodes and all that is actually there again and that other one was sort of a fake out then I think you need chemo and I think we’ve been stalling enough for a while that the inevitable is about to happen Mr. H____ you just, you’re gonna, we’re just gonna have to do it Patient: Okay. Doctor: and that’s with docetaxel and Taxotere is the name of the chemo and we do have studies with that so I just, you know, I always want to make sure we talk about that. So, you’d get on Taxotere just alone once every three weeks. It’s an hour infusion. Standard of care anywhere you go in the US. Patient: Okay. Doctor: and then our studies are Taxotere plus high-dose vitamin C versus just the Taxotere. So, two-thirds of the people will get vitamin C. The other one third will just get the chemo. So, everybody gets chemo no matter how I swing this

Patient: I think so. I think so, 'cause-- Doctor: Yeah, because the last time your PSA came down and, you know, I think this tearing, like I said, it could possibly be from the chemotherapy, so-- Patient: I mean, if I'm doin' good on it, Doctor: It’s very much Patient: -let's keep goin'. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I know I have an imaging scheduled for, what was it S____, the--? Healthcare Professional: Uh, we're going to do it the fourteeth. Patient: Fourteenth? Healthcare Professional: So it's two weeks from today. Doctor: So two weeks from now. Healthcare Professional: And then treatment on the twenty first.

Family Member: We’re good. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Any questions? Family Member: Questions? Patient: Um, do I need any medication? Family Member: No. She gave you the Promax. In a couple of weeks, you’ll need some more pain pills. Patient: Oh, okay. Family Member: Okay? Doctor: Okay. So should I give you a script today is what I’m thinking? Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Because uh that way you don’t have to scramble last minute. Doctor: What is he on? The Norco, right?

Patient: The twelfth, and we’ll be gone for the twentieth. We’re going to Phoenix then. Doctor: Okay. Let’s, we’ll incorporate that all in. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: That’s all. Or, if we have to, then we will start the twenty-first when you come back or the twenty-second. Patient: Gotcha. Okay. Family Member: Mm-hmm. Doctor: Plenty of time! Plenty of time. Patient: So, so, so it’s not bad news that …. Doctor: No, I don’t think it’s bad news at all. We were all kinda, “Ohhhhhh. Maybe there’s a thing in the liver or whatever.” You’re good. Patient: Good. Family Member: Oh, good. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Until we can go and talk about that. No rush. Plus your next shot I think is April fourth. So we may uh, you know, we’ll work on that, but you may even be, you come in at the same time, and we can use that same visit. So I’ll look at that. Okay? Any questions? Patient: I didn’t know that you - So that’s what I had? I had cancer, I mean, uh, I had pneumonia and-? Doctor: Pneumonia and the flu. Yeah. Yeah. Patient: The flu? Yeah. That’s what I had before. Doctor: Yeah. I think that’s what happened when I talked to your doctor. They were for sure about pneumonia. They were waiting on the flu results at the time. But I think they treated you like you had the flu, anyway, so. Okay. Patient: Right. That’s like I had before. It crippled me. I couldn’t walk. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: By the time there the next day they gave me some potassium and they gave me antibiotics. Doctor: Um hum. Um hum. Yeah. Patient: And was walking in an hour or two. Doctor: Yeah. And you were really dehydrated. Patient: Yeah I was.

Family Member: Okay, so you need to advise us and… Doctor: Well again I’m just getting more data as we’re talking here. Patient: I also sent saliva to do DNA test – Doctor: Uh huh. Patient: - and the thing has said it’s not hereditary. Family Member: That’s the copy. Doctor: Okay, I’ll take a look at it Patient: When I was in the hospital checking every day - Doctor: Today your creatinine is one point zero. And your liver tests are all normal. Your PSA is pending; it looks like – Patient: They didn’t know. Doctor: It just hasn’t resulted yet. Family Member: Uh, the last reading when we were here on the twelfth of November, the reading was seventeen for PSA. Did that corrected? Doctor: Seventeen.

Patient: Run down. Yeah, it did, it was making me really tired. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: But I mean, I was surviving--I was able to get by with work and stuff, it was-- Family Member: You got really--you were really, really tired. Doctor: I may just adjust you today because if we can keep that eye and, you know, everything else from getting worse-- Patient: Yeah, the drops have been wonderful. Doctor: --because the nerves affecting things is a big problem. If that happens, then that's tougher to reverse. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. So let's go one notch slightly lower in terms of your dose. Patient: Okay. Yeah, I missed it yesterday, I was going to come in all dressed up as a doctor, and-- Doctor: Yep. Healthcare Professional: So we just need to do a date clarification 'cause- so the pharmacy can use the last order the last time. Just have to change today’s date, so.

Family Member: No. Patient: No. It ain’t going to stop me. I’ve got to do what I’ve got to do. It ain’t going to stop me. I’ve got to be a superstar. It’s not going to stop me. Patient: Now that I’ll get you and we’ll shoot a video. Doctor: Oh. Patient: Video. Doctor: Oh, man. Yes! Let’s do it! You got to give me a heads up. Patient: Oh, yeah. I’ll give you a heads up. You don’t have to worry about it. Patient: You don’t have to fix all that. That ain’t our best. Family Member: Who makes the appointment for it? Doctor: You got to do it. So when you walk out, right where you checked in, they will give you the times that’s convenient to both of you. Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: They will scan and go when you’re done.

Family Member: Why don’t we just stop it. Doctor: So go ahead and stop it for now. And we’ll restart it once we feel comfortable that there’s no bleeding and you know… Patient: Okay so I’m off the aspirin. Even the little ones? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Totally off the aspirin. Healthcare Professional: Even the baby aspirin. Family Member: And that’s what B____ said. Patient: I know. Okay. Family Member: Um. Healthcare Professional: Let me get your reports copied. Family Member: Do you mind if we, is it possible to sit in here and read through the consent? Just so we have… Doctor: That’s fine. It’s just that do you want to - are you okay with doing that? Patient: No, no, let’s take our time.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.disagree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::disagree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Patient: None of that. Doctor: And any issues, any new issues urinating, anything like that? Patient: Uh, not, not on a frequent basis. Maybe once or twice I would have to urinate, um, since the last time I’ve seen you, maybe once or twice, I would have to urinate frequently. You know? Doctor: Okay. Patient: Uh. Doctor: Anything like burning or anything or just-? Patient: None of that. Doctor: And how just overall energy level since we stopped the study have you had? Noticed worsening, better, same? Patient: Well, uh, I could say, I don’t have as much energy as I had when I was on testosterone. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Right? So that, that has diminished. Uh, uh, let’s see, I, I’m just trying to think through the process because I’m still- Doctor: I mean, you’re still up? You’re still kind of doing the things you want to do? You’re not like-? Patient: Right. Right. Right. Right. Right. Yeah. Because we was on vacation for twelve days. So that, that threw off everything with me.

Family Member: Hum. So they’ll radiate? Doctor: Uhn-uhn. This stuff that’s liquid goes everywhere in the bone. Family Member: Ohh! Doctor: So it isn’t like he stands there and they only shoot it up like a bone injection. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: Uhn-uhn. You get an intravenous you know little catheter. Patient: And that’s going to be in me for six months. Doctor: Yeah, like they give it to you - it’s like one minute, and you’re done for the month. Family Member: Does he have to keep that catheter in there for the whole month? Doctor: No. Family Member: Oh good. Doctor: Like you put it in (makes mimicking sound) Family Member: So you wouldn’t suggest that he does a lot of walking.

Family Member: You know, I think that was the last refill. Let’s check it. Doctor: I think he needs to see us uh… Family Member: I think he’s gonna need more today. Healthcare Professional: Maybe S__ was waiting? Doctor: Yeah. Walgreens, Walmart, Healthcare Professional: Walmart pharmacy (phone dialing) Doctor: Oh you’re gonna call them and ask, perfect. Healthcare Professional: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. I will be back. I have to have S__ check and see but next time I’m gonna check your sugar so come and in fasting to get you blood work. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Then you can eat. Okay? Patient: Okay.
